text:
Hi I'm Kelis and I'm in the Food Tube kitchen,
today I'm gonna make smokey bacon Arepas.

Arepas are a really traditional Columbian
dish they cook them on every corner and there's

a million different ways to do it. I kinda
put my own twist on it and I've had some discussions

with some other Columbians they do not think
that bacon should be on them but I do so I

put bacon in mine just cos I put bacon in everything.
This is basically just really fine pre cooked

white cornmeal I get it at my market I've
got about 500 grams already measured out so

I'm just gonna put it in my bowl here then
I have a kettle of some already boiled water,

2 cups, cooking is temperamental and it depends
on your atmosphere, if you're in a really

humid place you might need less water if you're
in a super dry place like California where

I am from you might need more water. You wanna
make like a dough so if you see that it's

still really dry like this you know you need
some more water I was just recently in Columbia

and it was amazing because like you see all
these women making them on the corner with

open flames and one of the things that I thought
was cool was that it's like such a great foundation

for so many different things like you can
top it with anything you could put bacon in

it you could put onions in it you could put
jalapenos or it's a foundation for like this

plethora of amazing delicious things. You
want your dough consistency to be you want

it to be pliable like it needs to be able
to mould, you don't want it to be so wet to

the point where you can't get it to become
something but you don't want it to be so dry

to the point where you can still see the dry
grains you know? So I fried up some american

bacon if you're in the UK or in Europe then
this would be streaky smoked bacon and just

chop it up and added it to my arepa dough.
We love eating these for breakfast in my house

because they're quick and they're easy but
you really could have them any time in Columbia

they eat them all day. One is like one serving
I think that's more than enough it's like having

your little personal pizza. I've had mine
in the fridge for up to like a week they don't

usually last a week only because people eat
them but in theory if you were to keep them

in your fridge for a week I think they'd be
good. There's a lot of different ways you

can do these, you can do them in a toaster
oven to start them off I like doing them in

a pan with some butter and then finishing
them off on some open flame just because they'll

get a really good nice charred flavour colour.
It gets crispy crusty on the outside on both

sides and then just a little layer on the
inside is like soft and mushy and that's what

makes the whole perfect combo. Alright so
I'm gonna start my smoked bacon ones in there,

I'm gonna grate my cheese this is just queso
blanco I've done it with gouda I've done it

with gruyere, people think that Cotija is the
same as queso blanco it's very similar and

if you can't find queso blanco then I would
say go with Cotija but Cotija's a lot saltier,

this is extremely traditional light fluffy
wonderful and then this is literally just

finishing them off perfect for my arepas inside
when I don't feel like starting a barbecue,

almost done, I'm actually ready to put them
on our fire. They're such a treat, so good,

super versatile you can do all vegetarian
or chorizo or whatever but I mean the core

of them is that yeah they're gluten free by
nature because it's corn I suppose if you really

had to you could use oil instead of butter,
again it's a personal choice you don't need

to keep them on there too long. That is exactly
what you want, you want the burning bit it's

the best part do you hear that? Yep so these
also you wanna you don't wanna like make them

and then have them sitting you wanna serve
them right away because what happens is if

they're sitting on whatever plate or board
that you have them on for too long they get

like soggy again and then all that wonderful
charring and crisping is kind of a waste of

time. Okay now please look at this, look how
fantastic this cheese is like clouds its miraculous,

Columbia they'll heap like literally you'll
be like there's no way that I can eat all of

that but it's like so light and fluffy that
just like when you take a bite it just goes

away it's perfect. We've got some already
fried down chorizo like I said before there's

really no wrong answer here guys I've got
some ahi here like a salsa and it's got a

really nice fresh flavour because of all of
the cilantro I also have the recipe in my

book but really just so you know it's cilantro,
onion, garlic, habaneros, tomato, a little

bit of lime, vinegar, water done. So now you
get to try it it's my favourite part okay

let's see.... score! crunchy, soft, salty,
chorizo makes it get that really good flavour

to go with bacon the ahi has got like a fresh,
it's like a break to everything I want in

my mouth right now. If you like this recipe
there are tons more click the link below for

my book there's recipes from all over the
world like from Asia and Latin America and

classic American dishes I hope you enjoy them
I'm super excited about it
